justification: “We asked people to estimate their percentile (i.e., social-comparative standing) for a variety of health behaviors… Participants used a slider scale with a numerical readout to respond between 0 and 99.”
construct: Perceived social-comparative standing for health behaviors

justification: “Next, participants responded to 20 nonsocial frequency or proportion questions—henceforth called absolute questions…each question was answered on a dropdown menu or as a percentage entry.”
construct: Self-reported absolute frequency of each health behavior

measured_by: personal-frequency rating scale (1 = I don’t do this; 6 = I do this very frequently)
justification: “Participants gave 20 personal-frequency ratings (1 = I don't do this; 6 = I do this very frequently).”
“…and 20 commonness-among-students ratings (1 = very uncommon; 5 = very common).”
construct: Perceived commonness of behavior among peers

justification: “They completed the newly added absolute-other questions. For each of the 20 behaviors, they gave an absolute estimate about the behavior of the ‘typical University of Iowa student.’”
construct: Perceived frequency of the typical peer’s behavior

justification: “We added the 7-item expanded version of the Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT; Toplak, West, & Stanovich, 2014).”
“Among the demographic questions, we also asked participants to report their ACT scores or SAT scores.”

measured_by: healthiness categorization items (positive/negative; better to do more/less)
justification: “Participants answered healthiness items asking, ‘Would you consider these behaviors to be positive health behaviors or negative health behaviors?’ and ‘Is it better to do these behaviors more or less often than the average person does?’”
